intro: Echinopsilon eriophorus, commonly known as the narrowleaf burweed, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its small, spiny fruits that resemble burrs. The plant typically grows in dry, disturbed soils and is often found in grasslands and shrublands. Its leaves are narrow and covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss in arid environments. Echinopsilon eriophorus is adapted to thrive in harsh, sun-exposed conditions, making it a resilient species in its native range.
